awd_titl_txt: Comparative Evaluation of Ionic Transport Mechanisms in Solid-State Electrolytes
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRPTION: A key aspect towards achieving batteries with energy and power densities that are competitive with fossil fuel is to develop solid-state electrolytes for use as the membrane that separates the anode and cathode. The most important property of this membrane, which facilitates the electrochemical process associated with energy conversion, is to exhibit high ionic conductivity. This issue is why current battery technologies rely on liquid electrolytes. Solid-state electrolytes allow for a more compact form factor, safer operation, and better longevity of batteries, but their ionic conductivity must be improved. To accomplish this goal, various schools of thought and types of materials, including inorganic glasses, fine-grained ceramics, and composites containing an organic plasticizer are being pursued. To date, much of this work has been done by trial and error. In the present project, the optimal materials design criteria for solid-state electrolytes are identified through a comparative study that involves a series of carefully conceived experiments and atomistic computer simulations. This research reveals the underlying fundamental relationships between materials structure, their mechanical properties, and ionic conductivities, including the development of improved theoretical models for the interpretation of experimental findings, which are capable of predicting the optimal materials design for desired performance characteristics. 

TECHNICAL DETAILS: Solid-state battery electrolytes are key to the advancement of green renewable energy storage technologies. In this research, the materials design criteria are being developed for solid-state electrolytes that exhibit the required high transport rates and transference numbers for small charge carrier cations. Additionally, these electrolytes must maintain a mechanical rigidity sufficient to suppress lithium dendrite growth and safely separate electrodes in self-supporting device structures, and possess an electrochemical stability range wide enough to accommodate large electrode potential differences. The current scope of materials design concepts encompasses materials from crystalline to amorphous, and from inorganic to organic, and with this research the most effective approach is being identified. To this end, the decisive ionic transport mechanisms are systematically isolated by formulating a series of prototype materials systems, each one selectively exposing the influence on the cation mobility that specific structural features within the major materials types have, including interfacial structures in polycrystalline ceramics, plasticizer phases in hybrid organic-inorganic composites, and engineered defects in ion-exchanged oxide glasses. These experiments are coupled with extensive atomistic simulations to interpret experimental findings and to develop theoretical models that facilitate a reliable and transferrable design strategy for solid-state electrolytes. Undergraduate and graduate students, as well as postdoctoral fellows are engaged in research that provides training in both computational and experimental methods of investigation, and that advances the National Materials Genome Initiative mandate through the development of computational tools for predictive materials design.  The PI is establishing a bridge program to attract students graduating with a Masters degree from Minority-Serving Institutions (MSIs) with terminal programs, into Doctoral programs at the University of Michigan. He also helps organize the High School Teachers Materials Camp sponsored by ASM International and hosted by his department since 2002.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

por.por_cntn:
Overview – The objective of this research has been to create hybrid organic-inorganic solid electrolytes consisting of a load bearing nano-porous silica backbone, a high-mobility polymer phase occupying the pores, and a cation donor anchored to the backbone to ensure high cation transference numbers. To this end, we (i) developed synthesis and processing routes that provide control over the spatial arrangement of cation donor sites, i.e., defects that delineate the cation migration pathways within the plasticizer phase of hybrid organic-inorganic electrolytes, by optimizing the grafting site density on the inorganic backbone chain length distribution of polymer tethers; (ii) determined the relative importance of interfacial vs. bulk mobility in multi-phase and hybrid composite structures; and (iii) explored a new concept of engineered defects in amorphous solid electrolytes based on ion-exchange, replacing large cations with smaller ones. Materials synthesis, characterization, and predictive molecular simulation were synergistically combined.

Intellectual Merit – We discovered that for a given chemistry and composition, structural conditioning can result in increases of ionic conductivity by three orders of magnitude. Currently, chemistry and composition are the foremost design parameters canvassed for top performance. In this light, our finding has the potential to change the paradigm for research in this field. Based on the above materials design concept, e.g., a hybrid containing TFSI cation donors integrated into the silica backbone, anchored oligo-PEO (6-9 units), and 600MW PEO filler, we reliably achieve ionic conductivities of 10–3 S/cm at room temperature, with a lithium transference number exceeding 0.9. The potential exists for these figures of merit to further increase, given the proper processing conditions.

In PEO matrix composites with LATP particles precipitated from solution, we observe room temperature Li ion conductivities of 3.8·10–4 S/cm and achieve loading of dispersed particles up to 15 vol.%. The maximum conductivity occurs at around 12.5 vol.%, which indicates that ideal dispersion is nearly achieved. These findings support our conjecture regarding the development of a conductive interphase in composites with active fillers, even though the latter do not act as significant cation donors. Our analysis also shows that the interphase is characterized by stronger disorder, i.e., distortion and disruption of polymer alignment, and that the cation transport mechanism is associated with higher activation entropy compared to the bulk polymer.

We developed a new model for determining activation energies and entropies for ion transport based on the temperature dependence of the conductivity data that is meaningful within the framework of statistical mechanics, specifically when the data does not exhibit Arrhenius behavior. It is based on the assumption that the activation free energy in a supercooled glass forming system varies with temperature as a result of the structural reorganization in transition regime. This concept also applies to viscoelasticity.

We devised a new approach to assess cation mobility in amorphous structures when transport phenomena are based on rare events. To this end we apply Prony's analysis to the data obtained from MD simulations. As the network-solute system changes from compressive to sub-cavitation densities, we observe a sharp transition to high mobility when the material's equation of state changes from positive to negative curvature, i.e., when the system's energy landscape develops large numbers of unstable modes of motion. 

Broader Impacts – The availability of highly conductive electrolytes for Li battery technology directly affects our ability to store energy, deploy all-electric vehicles, and improve the operation of health-preserving devices and consumer products. It therefore has significant socio-economical impact.

Altogether, five graduate students, seven undergraduate students, and one visiting researcher have been trained in the ways of conducting scientific research, reviewing the scientific literature critically, analytical and creative thinking, and the systematic pursuit of scientific discovery. The students and postdoctoral researchers have developed a range of experimental and computational skills.

We conduct outreach through activities such as the Materials Camp for high school teachers, sponsored by the ASM International Foundation, held every summer at the University of Michigan Ann Arbor campus since 2002, which attracts 20 high school teachers from across the nation partake in this camp and learn about materials science and engineering in order to convey information about this field to their students. We are in the process of launching a MS-to-PhD springboard program for minority students from HBCU and HSI that have graduate programs ending with M.S. degrees, specifically in the area of computational science and engineering. Finally, we provided research opportunities for local high school students so to foster their interests in predictive materials development and relate the importance of computational material science.

 


Last Modified: 08/31/2022
Modified by: John Kieffer

Image
  • Cylindrical hybrid electrolytes rigidify first on their periphery, creating tensile stresses to build in the center. The network at the core of the disk reconditions, resulting in an up to three orders of magnitude higher conductivity in the center compared to the periphery.
    V. Keshishian and J. Kieffer, University of Michigan
    Copyrighted
    John Kieffer
    Inhomogeneities in sol-gel derived hybrid electrolytes
